I've received a lot of questions about prescription drug importation, so I wanted to share my thoughts with you.   Despite what some have claimed, I have challenged PhRMA on their top legislative priority and was an original cosponsor of the Medicare Prescription Drug Price Negotiation Act, which sought to allow the federal government to use its purchasing power to drive a hard bargain with manufacturers and negotiate lower prescription drug prices.    I also supported the Drug Supply Chain Security Act, which is now law and puts in place state-of-the-art tracking and tracing of pharmaceuticals through the supply chain here in the U.S. to protect consumers against the threat of counterfeit, mislabeled or diluted drugs.  While being able to afford your prescriptions can be a life or death issue, so can ingesting something that has been altered or counterfeited by someone trying to make a quick buck - here or anywhere else in the world. Both access and safety are critical issues and I have been focused on each.   On the importation vote, the promise of being able to access cheaper prescription drugs is obviously a goal I have long shared, but so is ensuring the integrity of those drugs.  I know a few folks have dismissed the legitimacy of safety issues because the industry has expressed some of them, but the FDA, World Health Organization, AARP and many others share my concern.   FDA commissioners for the past three U.S. Presidents – including this one – have outlined serious safety warnings and said that they do not have the resources to protect consumers when it comes to imports - even if they are shipped through Canada. The World Health Organization has suggested nearly 1 in 10 pills imported into the U.S. are counterfeited.  And even AARP has said that, "if reimportation is allowed, it is important that the FDA be provided the resources and authority to ensure the safety of re-imported drugs from Canada, and that technological and other safeguards be employed."   So during the vote, I discussed the issue with the amendment sponsors and told them, "Count me in on imports if we can ensure FDA safety standards."  If safety concerns were better addressed, I would have supported the amendment.  We know this is important, we hear you and I intend to make progress toward providing better prescription drug access and safety.   We must also not lose sight of the extra $1,000 a year seniors will pay for their prescriptions and the millions who will lose all of their health care if the Affordable Care Act is repealed.  We must work together and have a united front to hold the Trump Administration accountable and fight back against those who believe consumers don't matter and that profits are more important than people.

Senator Tom Udall and I are united in standing up to protect our treasured public lands. Here is our joint statement on Secretary Ryan Zinke's monument review report:   During Secretary Zinke’s review process, almost 3 million Americans — including thousands of New Mexicans – made their opinions clear. They believe our existing national monuments are vitally important to our economy, community and culture, and they don’t want them changed.    The Department of Interior’s report to the president completely ignores New Mexicans’ overwhelming support for the monuments, and doesn’t even offer specifics and meaningful data to back up their vague recommendations. It doesn’t come as a surprise that local voices were not taken into consideration, since Secretary Zinke declined to attend a town hall meeting on Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks and never even set foot in Rio Grande del Norte. It’s clear this report is a politically driven attempt by Washington to justify the administration’s extreme position that public lands should be privatized, leased or sold to the highest bidder.     In stark contrast to the rushed politically-driven review the Trump Administration holds in their hands, local communities, Tribes, lawmakers and previous administrations spent years working with local constituents and stakeholders to craft the most inclusive proposals possible. This administration took the opposite approach — they declined public hearings, made decisions behind closed doors, and kept their final recommendations hidden. What they have ended up with is a sloppy, inaccurate, and Washington-first work product devoid of local engagement.  And even now, New Mexicans — and all Americans — are in the dark about what is going to happen to these treasured places. The public deserves better than predetermined political conclusions based on hearsay and claims that are easily disproven if the Department had actually taken the time to listen to and work with local communities.    A decision to move forward with these recommendations would be both exceedingly unpopular and very likely illegal. We strongly urge the president to reject this sham report, honor the work by New Mexicans, and confirm that he will leave intact Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks, Rio Grande del Norte and all the other national monuments.

The President’s unprecedented move to drastically shrink Bears Ears and Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monuments in southern Utah tears at the heart of America’s conservation legacy and is a direct assault on sacred lands and tribal sovereignty. President Trump has denied future generations the opportunity to learn about the past and explore the remote mesas and canyons that have inspired visitors and inhabitants, dating back thousands of years.  In the century plus since Theodore Roosevelt signed the Antiquities Act into law, presidents from both political parties have used it to protect the places we all treasure and integral parts of who we are as Americans. Bears Ears and Grand Staircase-Escalante are unquestionably the types of places that the Antiquities Act was intended to protect for future generations. Dismantling protections for these landscapes sets a dangerous precedent that fuels an even larger campaign to attack many of our most treasured public lands across the nation.  I was proud to stand with southwestern tribes, including the Navajo Nation and Zuni Pueblo, who were part of an Inter-Tribal Coalition that called for monument protection for the sacred sites and irreplaceable cultural resources in Bears Ears. For the tribes who hold this land in deep reverence, Bears Ears National Monument and the thousands of historic and cultural sites within it serve as essential symbols of their rich history and continued perseverance.  In recent years, I’ve joined communities in New Mexico to welcome monument protections for Bears Ears and for two of the most spectacular culturally and ecologically significant places in our state—the Rio Grande del Norte and Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks. President Trump’s actions today threaten both of those community-driven monuments that permanently protected iconic landscapes, increased recreational access, and have proven to be major drivers for our local economies.  I’m confident that this shameful action will rightly face the same types of legal challenges as others pushed through by a White House hell-bent on appeasing a few extreme interests at the expense of the interests and values of the American people.  I urge the American people to continue making their voices heard to oppose this un-American action by the Trump Administration. We have a moral responsibility as a nation to our children and all future generations of Americans to protect and conserve our natural and cultural heritage.

The Republican Tax Scam is a missed opportunity at a time when our nation faces significant economic challenges in rural communities. Instead of giving tax breaks to special interests, we should be investing in what we know actually increases wages and accelerates economic growth. Rural communities need targeted actions to address specific challenges. We need to connect rural New Mexicans to high-speed internet, help small business owners get the loans they need to launch and expand their businesses, and ensure families can afford a college education and access quality health care coverage no matter where they live. We also need to focus on programs that are proven to reduce poverty and incentivize hard work, like the Earned Income Tax Credit and the Child Tax Credit, which effectively raise incomes for working families. I’ll continue doing everything in my power to stop the reckless Republican plan and fight for bipartisan, pragmatic solutions to build a bright future for New Mexico and our nation.

Today is Bill of Rights Day, which celebrates the first 10 amendments to the Constitution. These amendments protect our civil liberties and place important limits on the federal government’s power. The freedoms and protections guaranteed by the Bill of Rights form the bedrock of our most important rights and values. Over the centuries since the framers of the Constitution ratified the Bill of Rights, generations of Americans have given their lives to uphold them. We must all aspire to honor that sacrifice and defend these hard-won fundamental American principles against threats at home and abroad each and every day.

President Trump and Republicans in Congress have made it clear where their priorities stand. They’ve abandoned working American families while recklessly blowing up the deficit in order to reward their wealthy friends and corporations with a tax cut that they do not need. When their tax plan is fully implemented, millions of middle-class families will face a tax increase.  Republicans talked and talked about simplicity. But with all the loopholes and giveaways for special interests, Republicans have made the tax code more complex. They said they would reduce the number of tax brackets, but they didn’t. And, at the last minute, they inserted additional tax breaks for the wealthy, cutting the top tax rate for individuals with incomes of $500,000 or more.  Republicans also used the tax bill to undercut health care coverage that New Mexicans count on, repealing a key provision of the Affordable Care Act that will result in 13 million Americans losing their health insurance over the next decade. And health insurance premiums paid by many others will increase by about 10 percent in most years.  This tax plan puts at risk the jobs of public school teachers, police officers, and firefighters by capping the deduction for property taxes and state and local income taxes. They even opened up the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil and gas drilling.  The Republican plan fails to meet our country’s needs. It does not deliver tax relief to those who need it. It is also fiscally irresponsible, deepens inequality in the country, and it won’t do much to accelerate economic growth in New Mexico. I am extremely disappointed that my Republican colleagues jammed this legislation through both chambers without any input from Democrats, putting the interests of their donors and corporations ahead of those of the millions of families across this country who will be devastated by this tax plan.

As a member of the Senate Intelligence Committee, I remain committed to uncovering the full extent of Russia's interference in the 2016 election and ensuring that we create protections against similar actions from foreign actors going forward. The upper Gila is the last free-flowing and wild river in the American Southwest. The ecosystem that the Gila supports is so precious that we protected it nearly a century ago as the world’s first wilderness. Using our state’s Arizona Water Settlement funds to pay for ready-to-go water conservation projects, watershed restoration, and improvements to irrigation infrastructure that local communities have asked for would do far more to sustain future water needs in southwest New Mexico than wasting millions of dollars studying a costly and destructive Gila diversion project. New Mexicans deserve responsible, cost-effective, science-based solutions if we are to manage our limited water supplies and protect our natural heritage for future generations.
